title: Your favourite sans for setting body text
content: Any favoured sans you find set nicely at body text size?
author: Christian Teniswood

comments.content:
I have many, but these are my current favorites:

- [FF Balance](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=balance) - This has so much character merely because the stress is horizontal rather than vertical. Looks great every time I see it (which is sadly too rare).
- [FF Strada](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=strada) - Simple forms mixed with some organic terminals and a thoughtful italic. Mmm. [Another sample of FF Strada.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/static.flickr.com/14/20098053_1f82de0bbc_o.jpg)
- [FF Quadraat Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.10989.0.0) - There is experienced method behind the lack of uniformity.
- [FF Profile](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.11100.0.0) - Has a friendly air for less serious texts.
- [FF Legato](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=legato) - This groundbreaking design requires some reading to fully appreciate. [Start here.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/typographi.com/000969.php)
- [Versa Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=versa%20sans) - More brilliance from a Dutch master.
- [Freight Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=GF.118889.0.0) - Excellent [complimentary styles](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.joshuadarden.com/) available too. I recommend loosening the spacing a tad.
- [Amplitude](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=amplitude) - The Normal and Wide are really great for small print.
- [Lisboa Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.veer.com/partner/link.aspx?i=1048&c=4&p=products/typedetail.aspx?image=FOT0000081) - Veer mailed a sans poster a few weeks ago and this new release was the most impressive on the sheet.
[Stella](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.vllg.com/Feliciano/Stella/mudTyper+Weights/) is beautiful, and has all of the necessary parts.

All things being equal, the one that has the best shot at good readability: Legato. And it doesn't hurt that it's the most culturally-significant design since... possibly the beginning.

hhp
I use mine: [Mundo Sans.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fonts.com/FindFonts/RecentReleases/2003/02-02-2003.htm) It's meant for small sizes. There's a PDF to see it in use.

My current fav and 'corporate type'.: ' [John Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.stormtype.com/jsans.html)', by František Štorm..

_( And, I am still saving my money for additional StormType faces, like 'Metron' and 'Elektra'.. :)_

Dav

I have been using FF Quadraat Sans quite a bit lately. Possibly due to the fact that it is one of the few that I own, but nevertheless! Also, I have always admired FF Scala Sans, even more so that Scala Serif. FF Balance and FF Legato are pretty magic, as mentioned above. John Sans would be fun to play with, so much character!

Kris.
Mundo looks nice. Fonts.com has the worst "previews" though.
Amplitude could work, but no italics.

Thanks guys,

So many excellent suggestions ... I'm looking forward to setting some of my work in aforementioned fonts.

Cheers everyone, much appreciated.

Christian

I received [this book](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/product/0810949652) for Christmas, and it is set in [Scala Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150322223818/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=scala%20sans). The spacing of this typeface has always been a bit problematical, but I'm impressed once again by how well it works for continuous text of this sort, i.e. interrupted by frequent illustrations that readers will typically pause to enjoy. This is the sort of context in which a sans serif can work quite well.
